conclusion: Determine the electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals by calculating contributions from each charge and summing them vectorially.
The square has side length L, and the intersection of the diagonals is the center of the square, equidistant from all vertices A, B, C, D.
The distance from the center to any vertex is the diagonal's half-length: r = sqrt(2)L/2.
Electric field due to a point charge q at a distance r is given by Coulomb's law: E = k|q|/r^2.
Substituting r = sqrt(2)L/2, the magnitude of the electric field due to any charge at the center is E = 2k|q|/L^2.
Positive charges (+q) produce electric fields pointing away from the charge, and negative charges (-q) produce fields pointing toward the charge.
Electric field directions at the center: +q at A and B point away, -q at C and D point toward.
The square is symmetric, and charges are placed symmetrically, simplifying calculations.
Electric fields from +q at A and B combine vectorially, as do fields from -q at C and D.
Each electric field has x- and y-components; calculate components for one charge using symmetry.
Electric field due to +q at A makes a 45-degree angle with axes: Ex = E/sqrt(2), Ey = E/sqrt(2).
Similarly, electric fields due to +q at B, -q at C, and -q at D have components along x- and y-axes.
